Award.AwardTitle: Symposium on Undegraduate Research - LS-XXXI-SanJose; San Jose, California; October 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides travel support for student participation in the Symposium on Undergraduate Research to be held at the Laser Science XXXI Conference. This conference is of great importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States because almost all work in this area involves lasers in some way. The support of students through this award makes a substantial contribution to the education and training of future scientists. Students who graduate with a background in atomic, molecular, and optical physics acquire a broad range of knowledge and skills that enable them to contribute to progress in many areas of science and technology.

The Laser Science XXXI Conference, which this award supports, is a joint meeting of the American Physical Society's Division of Laser Science and the Optical Society of America's annual meeting to be held in San Jose, CA in October, 2015. This Conference offers an opportunity for students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community. Support is provided only for US students (students enrolled in US universities).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The fifteenth annual DLS Symposium on Undergraduate Research at LS-XXXI was held in San Jose, CA on Monday, 19 October, 2015. The Symposium has grown from ten presentations in 2001 to forty-five this year on projects done at about 40 universities or research institutes. This was not quite the largest one ever, but is near the capacity limit for meetings in the present format. These Symposia have brought over 500 students to our annual meetings to present what are often the first research papers of their budding careers.  Programs, articles, further information, and photos from previous symposia at our annual meetings are on the DLS website http://www.aps.org/units/dls/meetings/symposium/ and the Stony Brook Laser Teaching Center website at http://laser.physics.sunysb.edu/research-symposium/.

Our 2015 Symposium had a schedule that was different from the previous ones because of a change of the OSA sessioning and events schedule.  It began with a served, family-style welcoming dinner on Sunday evening, 18 October, at the Bo-Town Chinese restaurant only 100 m from the Ramada San Jose hotel where the students were housed. There was plenty of good food, well prepared, and nicely served. The evening included remarks by  the national director of the Society of Physics Students, Sean Bentley.  Afterwards students and faculty guests lingered in conversations with each other and with a few other guests.  It was a pleasant time to make acquaintances with one another, enjoy casual time with the many mentors who were there, and discuss the forthcoming adventure. 

The FiO/LS conference events began at 8:00 AM Monday morning with Plenary Session talks by several outstanding people.  The session ended at 10:00 AM, and our poster session began then. The session had 35 papers whose abstracts were published in an eight-page program (copy attached) and was presided by Prof. Jenny Magnes from Vassar College.  The entire area was abuzz with conversation and discussion as the delighted presenters talked about their work to interested scientists and fellow students.  It was attended by a large number of conferees, many of whom were highly visible, senior optical scientists.  Prof. Metcalf had been called the previous day by Emily Conover, a reporter sent by APS to cover the meeting, and his response to her was that she should talk with the students.  She came to the poster session, interviewed quite a few students, and wrote a wonderful front-page article for APS News (copy attached) and posted at https://www.aps.org/publications/apsnews/201511/undergrads.cfm.

The poster session ended at 12:45, we gathered for a group photo (copy attached), and enjoyed a sandwich lunch in the Glen Ellen room of the Fairmont Hotel. During the lunch the students were privileged to hear remarks from several distinguished guests and faculty mentors who had joined us.  These included Kristan Corwin, Dima Budker, Jenny Magnes, Hong Lin, Chad Hoyt, Emilty Conover, and others.  It was indeed convenient to have the poster session just outside the room of the luncheon and the oral sessions.

The first of two oral presentation sessions began at 1:30, the second session lasted until 4:00, and each had five talks.  The first one was presided by Prof. Chad Hoyt from Bethel University and the second by Prof. Kristan Corwin of Kansas State Univ. Besides students and mentors, the audience included quite a few regular conference attendees over the course of the afternoon. (These attendees may have learned about the session from the programs included in their registration package, or from announcements at the plenary session.)  The quality of the talks was uniformly very high, and the two oral sessions were an unqualified success.  Students enjoyed snacks between the sessions, courtesy of one of our corporate sponsors, Thorlabs.  A sign board with logos of all the corporate sponsors was prominently displayed at all Symposium meals and sessions (copy attached).

It was gratifying that these very young scientists could give their first presentations at a professional meeting, and it was clearly a memorable event for them.  Fifteen of this year's presenters were female, an impressive representation and above the national average among undergraduate physics students. 

 

 

 

            This year again we also enjoyed significant corporate support that is detailed below.  In addition there was a large donation from AIP through SPS. Also, Thorlabs sent wonderful snack boxes that were enjoyed in the break between sessions. Several acknowledgement posters were prominently displayed at all Symposium events (copy attached). 

            The entire Symposium was organized and arranged by Prof. Harold Metcalf of Stony Brook University. I benefited from several people from OSA.  We anticipate that the Symposium will be repeated at FiO/LS in Rochester next October, and information can be had from the DLS leadership, and at the DLS website http://www.aps.org/units/dls/.
